title: Classes & Objects (Building Your Own Types)

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: Defines a new class (blueprint). Use PascalCase naming: class Person, class BankAccount. Class keyword followed by name and { }.
Field definition. public means accessible from outside. Type (string, int, etc.) then field name. These are the DATA the object holds.
Creates a NEW instance (object) from the class. new keyword allocates memory and initializes the object. Returns reference to the new object.
Dot notation accesses fields. person.Name gets the Name field. person.Age = 25 sets the Age field. Each object has its own copy of fields!

challenge.instructions:
Create a student management system!

1. Define a Student class with fields:
   - Name (string)
   - StudentID (string)
   - Grade (int - 0-100)
   - IsPassing (bool - true if Grade >= 60)

2. Create a List<Student> to hold students

3. Add at least 5 students with various grades

4. Calculate and display:
   - All students with their info
   - Class average grade
   - How many students are passing
   - Highest and lowest grades with student names

5. Find and display all failing students (Grade < 60)

Example output:
=== STUDENT ROSTER ===
Alice (S001): 85 - PASSING
Bob (S002): 55 - FAILING
...

Class Average: 74.2
Passing: 3/5 students
Highest: Alice (85)
Lowest: Bob (55)

Failing students:
- Bob (S002): 55
challenge.hint: Define class with public fields. Use new Student { Name = "...", Grade = 85 } object initializer syntax. students.Average(s => s.Grade) for average. students.Count(s => s.IsPassing) counts passing. .OrderByDescending(s => s.Grade).First() finds highest.
commonStickingPoints: Forgetting 'new' keyword: Student s = Student(); is ERROR! Must use: Student s = new Student(); to create instance. 'new' allocates memory for object.
Null reference: Student s; s.Name = "Alice"; crashes! Must initialize first: Student s = new Student(); THEN s.Name = "Alice". Uninitialized objects are null!
Class vs Object confusion: Class is the blueprint/template. Object is the instance. Person is class. person1 = new Person() creates object. Can have many objects from one class!
Field access without object: Can't do Name = "Alice" directly! Must use object: person.Name = "Alice". Fields belong to objects, not floating in air!
